metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth is made of semi-solid rock that moves very slowly and causes surface changes such as volcanic eruptions?

answers.explanation: The crust is the thin, solid outer layer of Earth.
The mantle consists of hot, slowly flowing rock beneath the crust.
The outer core is a liquid layer made of iron and nickel.
The inner core is a solid sphere at the centre of Earth.

questions.question: The inner-most layer of Earth is composed mainly of solid iron and nickel kept solid by immense pressure. What is this layer called?

answers.explanation: Despite its high temperature, the inner core remains solid because of the great pressure at Earth’s centre.

questions.question: On which layer of the Earth do all landforms, oceans and human-made structures exist?

answers.explanation: The crust is Earth’s outer shell where we live and where surface features are found.

questions.question: Write the four main layers of the Earth in order from the surface to the centre.

answers.content: Crust, mantle, outer core, inner core
answers.explanation: This sequence starts with the thin outer crust and ends with the solid inner core.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section diagram of the Earth showing all four main layers. Use a different colour for each layer and include one sentence describing the temperature or composition of each layer.

answers.content: Student provides a clearly labelled, colour-coded diagram with sentences describing the crust (thin, solid rock), mantle (hot, semi-solid rock), outer core (liquid iron/nickel), and inner core (solid iron/nickel, hottest layer).
answers.explanation: Full marks awarded when all layers are accurately placed, labelled, colour-coded and described.

questions.question: What is the main cause of an earthquake?

answers.content: A sudden release of energy when tectonic plates slip past one another
answers.explanation: Stress builds up where plates grind together until it is suddenly released, causing seismic waves.

answers.content: Phases of the Moon pulling on Earth’s crust
Erosion by wind and rain over many years

questions.question: In the Mars bar model used in class, the solid chocolate coating best represents which part of Earth?

answers.explanation: The hard outer layer of the chocolate bar mimics the rigid lithosphere.

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using the causal connective ‘so’.
“The earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula, _____ the land rose up and changed the shape of the coastline.”

answers.explanation: ‘So’ correctly links the cause (earthquake) to the effect (land uplift and coastline change).

questions.question: A powerful earthquake that occurs beneath the ocean floor can most directly produce which natural hazard?

answers.explanation: Under-sea quakes displace large volumes of water, generating series of giant waves.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram showing two tectonic plates at a fault line. Use arrows to indicate the direction of movement and annotate where an earthquake could occur.

answers.content: Sample diagram includes: two blocks (plates) meeting at a fault; arrows showing opposite or converging motion; label ‘fault line’; label ‘epicentre’ or ‘earthquake occurs here’.
answers.explanation: A correct drawing demonstrates conceptual understanding, not artistic skill.

questions.question: The point on Earth’s surface directly above the focus of an earthquake is called the:

answers.explanation: It is vertically above the point where the rocks actually slip.

questions.question: Australia experiences relatively few large earthquakes mainly because:

answers.content: It lies in the middle of a tectonic plate, far from plate boundaries
answers.explanation: Plate interiors build up less stress than active boundaries.

answers.content: It is located on the equator
Its landmass is too small to store tectonic energy

questions.question: Describe one way an earthquake can quickly change a landscape, referring to what you observed in the Mars bar model.

answers.content: When the plates collided, the ‘crust’ buckled and cracked, showing how real land can rise, fold or split to form new ridges and deep cracks during an earthquake.
answers.explanation: Answer links model observation (buckling chocolate) with rapid surface change (uplift, faulting).

questions.question: Define the term ‘landscape’ and give one natural and one built example.

answers.content: Landscape is the collection of natural and built features in an area; e.g., a mountain range (natural) and a bridge (built).
answers.explanation: Definition matches lesson usage and provides both types of features.

questions.question:
Which connective in the sentence below signals cause and effect?
“The earthquake struck, so many roads cracked open.”

answers.explanation: ‘So’ links the cause (earthquake) to its effect (cracked roads).

questions.question: Which term describes molten rock that is still beneath Earth’s surface?

answers.explanation: Molten rock is called magma while it is underground; once it reaches the surface it is called lava.

questions.question: Which of the following is a constructive (positive) effect of a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Creation of fertile soils for farming
answers.explanation: Minerals in volcanic ash weather to form very nutrient-rich soils.

questions.question: Explain how a volcanic eruption can be both destructive and constructive. Give one example of each.

answers.content: Sample answer: A volcanic eruption can destroy landscapes and settlements when lava, ash and pyroclastic flows cover them (destructive). However, over time the erupted material breaks down to create very fertile soil that farmers can use to grow crops (constructive).

questions.question: In the class volcano model, which substance reacts with vinegar to create the ‘eruption’?

answers.explanation: Baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) reacts with vinegar to release carbon dioxide gas, causing the foamy eruption.

questions.question: Most volcanoes form along the edges of large moving pieces of Earth’s crust called:

answers.explanation: Interactions at tectonic plate boundaries allow magma to rise to the surface and form volcanoes.

questions.question: List two immediate changes to the landscape that can occur when a volcano erupts.

answers.content: Examples: new landforms such as lava flows and cones; burial of land under ash; formation of craters; creation of volcanic islands.

questions.question: Which causal connective best links an immediate effect to its knock-on effect in a sentence?

answers.explanation: ‘Because’ shows cause and effect, connecting the immediate change to its consequence.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram of the class volcano model. Include the magma (baking-soda mixture), vent, lava flow and ash cloud.

answers.content: Teacher to assess whether key parts are drawn and correctly labelled.

questions.question: Pompeii was buried in 79 AD by the eruption of which volcano?

answers.explanation: Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 AD, covering Pompeii in ash.

questions.question: Why are soils formed from volcanic ash often very fertile?

answers.content: Volcanic ash weathers into soil rich in minerals such as phosphorus, potassium and trace elements that plants need, so crops grow well there.

questions.question: What is weathering?

answers.content: The breaking down of rocks on Earth’s surface by natural forces.
answers.explanation: Weathering is the gradual breakdown of rocks by water, wind, temperature changes and living things.

answers.content: The movement of broken rock from one place to another.
answers.explanation: This is erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: Molten rock cooling inside a volcano.
answers.explanation: This describes igneous rock formation, not weathering.

answers.content: The change of liquid water to water vapour.
answers.explanation: This is evaporation, part of the water cycle.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an agent of weathering discussed in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Moving water is an important agent of weathering.
Wind is an agent of weathering.
Plants can wedge roots into rocks causing weathering.
Lightning is not identified as a regular agent of weathering in this lesson.

questions.question: In your own words, explain the difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Weathering breaks rocks into smaller pieces where they are. Erosion carries those pieces away to a new place.
answers.explanation: Students should show that weathering is the breakdown process and erosion is the transport process.

questions.question: During the sugar-cube investigation, what represented the force causing weathering?

answers.explanation: The lid simply kept the cubes inside the jar.

answers.content: Shaking the jar so the cubes knocked together
answers.explanation: Collisions between cubes model rocks grinding against each other in nature.
The paper was only used to make observations visible.
Time is important in real weathering but was not the force in this model.

questions.question: Describe one way plants can cause rocks to weather.

answers.content: Plant roots grow into cracks in rocks and as the roots thicken they force the crack wider, breaking the rock apart.
answers.explanation: Root action widens cracks and splits rocks, a form of biological weathering.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows how moving water weathers rock along a river bank. Your diagram should include arrows to show water flow and labels for sand/particles hitting the rock.

answers.content: Student provides a labelled sketch clearly showing flowing water, rock face, particles striking rock and an explanatory caption.
answers.explanation: Award full marks when key elements (water flow arrow, rock, impacting particles, labels) are present and correctly linked to weathering.

questions.question: In the model paragraph about water weathering rocks, which word is used as a causal connective that was NOT taught in lessons 2 or 3?

answers.explanation: "because" does not appear in the paragraph.
"so" was introduced earlier.
This connective was taught earlier.
"due to" is the new causal connective identified in the paragraph.

questions.question: What is the scientific term for the movement of rocks, soil and sand from one place to another?

answers.explanation: Weathering is the breaking down of rock into smaller pieces.
Deposition is when sediments are dropped or settle in a new location.
Erosion is the process that moves weathered material to a new location.
Sedimentation is another name for deposition, not movement.

questions.question: During the tray investigation, which variable was CHANGED to make the test fair?

answers.content: The amount of water poured into each tray
answers.explanation: The amount of water stayed the same in all trials.

answers.content: The steepness of the slope under each tray
answers.explanation: Only the number of books/blocks (slope) was changed.
Each trial used the same style of tray.

answers.content: The kind of sediment (sand vs. soil) placed in the tray
answers.explanation: All trays contained the same damp sand.

questions.question: Which tray is predicted to experience the GREATEST amount of erosion?

answers.explanation: Flat surfaces allow water to move slowly, creating little erosion.
A gentle slope increases erosion, but not as much as a steep slope.
A steep slope causes faster-moving water, giving it more force to erode.

answers.content: All trays are predicted to erode equally
answers.explanation: Different slopes change the speed and force of water.

questions.question: Explain why faster-moving water has a greater ability to erode sediment.

answers.content: When water moves faster it has more kinetic energy/force, so it can pick up and carry larger and more sediment particles away.
answers.explanation: Speed gives water more kinetic energy, increasing its erosive force.

questions.question: In Aboriginal Dreaming stories such as 'Super Snake', landforms are often explained by cultural narratives. In modern Earth science, which NATURAL force discussed in this lesson helps create similar landforms?

answers.explanation: Plate tectonics was not the focus of this lesson.
Wind can erode, but the lesson investigation centred on moving water.

answers.content: Moving water causing weathering and erosion
answers.explanation: The lesson investigates how flowing water shapes landforms.

answers.content: Heat from the Sun melting rocks
answers.explanation: Solar heating was not part of this erosion lesson.

questions.question: During the investigation, students poured the SAME volume of water into each tray. Give one reason why keeping the volume the same makes the test fair.

answers.content: It ensures that only the slope (steepness) affects erosion, not the amount of water/force added.
answers.explanation: Changing only one variable is essential for a fair test.

questions.question: Which real-world example BEST illustrates water erosion at work?

answers.content: Formation of sand dunes in the Sahara Desert
answers.explanation: Sand dunes are mainly shaped by wind erosion.

answers.content: Creation of the Twelve Apostles sea stacks along Victoria’s coast
answers.explanation: These limestone stacks are the result of coastal water erosion.

answers.content: Cracking of rocks due to freeze-thaw action
answers.explanation: Freeze-thaw is a form of weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: Cooling of lava to form igneous rock
answers.explanation: Rock cooling is unrelated to erosion.

questions.question:
Draw and label a simple diagram that shows how slope affects the speed of water flow and the amount of sediment deposited. Include: 
• A flat river channel, gentle slope, and steep slope
• Arrows to show water speed
• Areas where most sediment is deposited

answers.content: Student diagram must include three side-by-side sketches: flat, gentle, steep. Water arrows become longer from flat to steep, and sediment deposits are shown increasing in trays with steeper slopes. Labels for 'flat', 'gentle', 'steep', 'fast water', 'slow water', and 'sediment' should be present.
